Saying "the hardest part is showing up" never resonated with me because doing yoga didn't feel like the hardest part, all the poses did. But since I've been coming off anti depressants (good reasons!), the withdrawal effets are knocking me about so much that turning up has now become the hardest part. I have horrible indigestion, weird zaps, I often feel like my nerves detect the ground a second too late, my limbs feel like fuzzy velvet, and I am fighting bad back pain due to sleeplessness.

Sometimes I miss a day. It's Feb 9th and I'm on day 18 and I started on day one. I try not to think "I wish she wouldn't congratulate me for being here because it reminds me of the days I wasn't, and she is congratulating people on the days I wasn't here!!". But I remember to remind myself that this is my journey. Someone else's struggles are not mine to compare to, and I believe it ruins any healing they have done when I (in my mind) think others don't deserve praise for turning up on days I didn't.

I do get frustrated when Adrienne keeps talking, but I remember that I used to love it because it kept yoga fun and inviting, whereas now I just wanna get through it so I can go back to being in regular discomfort. I'm so glad I was reminded today that everyone is different, and I don't get to me impatient because something that is designed to be soothing isn't going at my pace.
Hang in there Megan, coming off anti depressants is tough.  Your whole perception and experience get distorted without you knowing.  I hope you are going OK, and I wish you the best.

Day 18: I showed up! I survived! Nothing else matters.

Seriously though: I missed a bunch of days in a row for several reasons, and they happened, and they don't matter any more. What matters is being here on the mat again, and the intention to be back tomorrow. To always come back, even if there's a gap. And I've got that.

In other related news, I think I need a literal yoga mat. While I didn't do great at connecting to center today, I did feel very very firmly in my whole body that finding my center is almost impossible if I don't have a good base to start from--and there is not enough friction on my living room rug to ever feel truly secure in my base. I CAN do the wide-legged stances and ground into my feet. I have that strength. But when I'm using nearly all the strength I have just to press into the ground so I don't instantly slip into a wider splits than my body can handle, there's none left to find center with. It's a disadvantage I haven't even really paid attention to playing with, and it's HARD.

So. A real yoga mat. Continued determination. It all comes from there.

When I started doing yoga about 7 years ago, it was as a way to stretch and recover from running or as a way to gently cross-train for running. I was in it for the workout and didn't really care about looking inward or cultivating the connection of the mind to the body. Since then, I've injured my knee and can no longer run, and I have returned to yoga with a much different approach. At a low point in my health and physical fitness in late November, I started doing the 30-day Yoga Camp series and gained so much direction from each practice and from journaling about the mantras. I ended that series just in time for Breath, and this has been a beautiful journey in slowing down and appreciating inner strength. At a time when thousands of people with covid are struggling to breathe on ventilators and the phrase "I can't breathe" is a rallying cry for social justice, the theme of breath is powerful and so, so precious. I really appreciate how I'm learning to move and open up from the inside out, and today's focus on the center may be my favorite practice of this series so far.
